awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Teams:  Intelligent Driver Assistance System Enabled by Connected Vehicle Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to change the way vehicles are driven to save energy, which will reduce fuel consumption and pollution near public roadways.  The first iteration of the technology will be in the form of recommendations made to drivers to affect velocity at different points along a route.  With the recent advancement to autonomous driver system implementation, this technology can be applied by directly interconnecting with the automated control systems rather than working through driver recommendations.  The safety of highways and all roadways will be enhanced with the system to recommend a maximum velocity prior to reaching road curves, preventing tipping and sliding.  Furthermore, less maintenance and longer lasting parts on vehicles such as brake replacements, tire replacements, and engine and transmission work will be needed.  This will benefit all of society in the form of reduced transportation cost.  

This I-Corps project is the result of studies done in the field of control systems. Specifically, control systems which optimize velocity to minimize energy consumption over a driving route through the implementation of dynamic programming.  The technology uses vehicle characteristics such as mass, air drag coefficients, and motor efficiency, as well as altitude and heading to determine the speed profile which is a minimum for a given route, while still adhering to local speed laws.  The technical results which the project is based stems from simulations done in Matlab concerning all these parameters in different situations and environments.  The initial simulations have shown a 16% energy saving for city driving in a scenario.  The amount of energy saving will be highly situational and will likely vary widely depending on the vehicle studied and circumstances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we completed a proof of concept electric vehicle (EV) platform with a top tilting section to further test initial customer feedback on efficient and recreational EVs.  An aluminum frame was built and a reinforced plywood top structure, and the vehicle was brought to public locations to obtain potential customer feedback.  This feedback was generally positive with some fundamental questions about vehicle range, utility, and reliability.  

The maximum speed of the proof of concept was set to 8 mph to be safe, however the vehicle is capable of 28 mph, with lightweight lithium batteries in the base of the platform.  We took the proof of concept to a local Tesla supercharger to interview many EV drivers and get a sense for the type of customer who would be interested.  This was formed by doing hundreds of previous interviews in the general EV space, including personal EV drivers as well as business owners of vehicles such as warehouse forklifts.  

The team chose to cater to the personal recreational EV market, as from the interviews there was a sense of an opening and need here.  Where many traditional EVs exist and are well developed, there are very few available options for recreational EVs, with most small utility vehicles being gas powered.  Also it was noted that doing something unique and differentiated would be of value through speaking with many Carver One owners, which is a tilting vehicle previously produced in Europe.  


Last Modified: 02/02/2022
Modified by: Wesley Connor
